entry.title: Introducing Orion-Belt - Open Source PAM for Modern Infrastructure
entry.summary: After months of development and testing in production environments, I'm releasing Orion-Belt as an open-source Privileged Access Management system. This project started from a practical need: managing secure SSH access across multiple machines without the complexity and cost of enterprise solutions.
entry.content:
After months of development and testing in production environments, I'm releasing Orion-Belt as an open-source Privileged Access Management system. This project started from a practical need: managing secure SSH access across multiple machines without the complexity and cost of enterprise solutions.

Why Another PAM Solution?​

Commercial PAM solutions like Teleport offer excellent features but come with licensing costs that can be prohibitive for smaller teams, homelabs, and organizations just starting their security journey. Orion-Belt provides a self-hosted alternative that covers the essential requirements:

  • Zero-trust architecture using reverse SSH tunnels
  • Fine-grained access control with relationship-based permissions
  • Complete session recording for audit and compliance
  • Temporary access workflows with approval mechanisms
  • Extensible plugin system for custom integrations

Architecture Decisions​

The design prioritizes security and simplicity. Agents on target machines initiate outbound connections to the gateway, eliminating the need for inbound firewall rules. This reverse tunnel approach means your infrastructure remains unexposed even as you provide SSH access through the gateway.

Access control uses OpenFGA for relationship-based permissions, allowing natural expressions like "alice can access machine-32 as root" or "bob can access any machine in the production environment as the deploy user."

Current Status​

Version 0.2.0 is stable and running in production. The core functionality is complete:

  • Gateway server with SSH/SCP proxy and REST API
  • Lightweight agents for Linux systems (Alpine, Debian, Ubuntu, RHEL)
  • Custom client tools (osh for SSH, ocp for SCP)
  • PostgreSQL backend for persistence
  • Session recording with playback capability

The next major release (0.3.0) will add multi-factor authentication and SSH Certificate Authority support.

Getting Started​

Installation takes about 10 minutes. The documentation covers setup for the gateway server, deploying agents, and configuring your first connection. Docker images are available, and installation scripts support multiple Linux distributions.

Check the Quick Start guide for detailed instructions.

Contributing​

The project is open for contributions. I'm particularly interested in:

  • Testing on different Linux distributions
  • Bug reports and use case feedback
  • Documentation improvements
  • Plugin development examples

Visit the GitHub repository to get involved.

entry.title: How Reverse SSH Tunneling Works in Orion-Belt
entry.summary: One of the key features of Orion-Belt is its use of reverse SSH tunnels to establish connections. This architectural choice eliminates the need for inbound firewall rules on target machines, but how does it actually work?
entry.content:
One of the key features of Orion-Belt is its use of reverse SSH tunnels to establish connections. This architectural choice eliminates the need for inbound firewall rules on target machines, but how does it actually work?

The Problem with Traditional SSH Access​

Traditional SSH requires opening port 22 (or another SSH port) on each target machine to accept incoming connections. This creates several challenges:

  • Firewall management becomes complex as the fleet grows
  • Each exposed port is a potential attack surface
  • Dynamic IPs and NAT complicate access
  • Monitoring and logging are fragmented across machines

Reverse Tunneling Approach​

Orion-Belt inverts this model. Instead of clients connecting directly to target machines, the target machines connect outbound to the gateway server. When a user wants to SSH into a machine, the gateway routes the connection through the existing tunnel.

Here's the flow:

  1. Agent on target machine establishes persistent SSH connection to gateway
  2. Agent registers itself and maintains the connection
  3. User authenticates with gateway and requests access to target
  4. Gateway verifies permissions and routes SSH session through existing tunnel
  5. User's session appears as a normal SSH connection to target machine

Benefits​

This architecture provides several advantages:

Security: Target machines never listen for incoming connections. Only one component (the gateway) needs to be internet-accessible.

Simplicity: No firewall rules needed on target machines. Just one outbound connection.

Observability: All access flows through a single point, making audit logs comprehensive and consistent.

Flexibility: Works behind NAT, with dynamic IPs, and across complex network topologies.

Implementation Details​

The agent uses Go's golang.org/x/crypto/ssh package to create the reverse tunnel. The connection includes automatic reconnection logic and heartbeat mechanisms to maintain connectivity.

On the gateway side, the SSH proxy maintains a registry of active tunnels and routes incoming user sessions to the appropriate agent connection. Session data passes through the gateway, enabling real-time monitoring and recording without compromising end-to-end encryption of the SSH protocol itself.

Trade-offs​

This approach does introduce a single point of failure (the gateway), which is why high availability features are planned for v1.0. The gateway must also handle the multiplexing of potentially hundreds of concurrent sessions, requiring careful resource management.

For most deployments, these trade-offs are acceptable given the security and operational benefits.

entry.title: Using Orion-Belt to Manage Homelab Access
entry.summary: Managing SSH access for a homelab presents unique challenges. You want secure remote access without exposing services directly to the internet, but you also don't want the complexity of enterprise solutions. Here's how Orion-Belt fits this use case.
entry.content:
Managing SSH access for a homelab presents unique challenges. You want secure remote access without exposing services directly to the internet, but you also don't want the complexity of enterprise solutions. Here's how Orion-Belt fits this use case.

The Homelab Access Problem​

A typical homelab might include:

  • Multiple servers running different services
  • Virtual machines for testing and development
  • Network equipment requiring CLI access
  • Raspberry Pis and other IoT devices

You need SSH access to all of these from outside your home network, but opening SSH ports to the internet is risky, and managing VPN access for every device becomes tedious.

Orion-Belt as a Solution​

With Orion-Belt, you deploy the gateway server as your single internet-facing access point. This can run on a small VPS or even within your homelab behind a reverse proxy.

Each device in your homelab runs the lightweight Orion-Belt agent, which connects outbound to the gateway. No inbound ports needed on your home network except for the gateway itself.

Example Setup​

For a homelab with 5 machines:

# Gateway on VPS (Ubuntu 22.04)
./install-gateway.sh

# Agent on each homelab machine
curl -sSL https://orion-belt.pages.dev/install-agent.sh | bash

The installation scripts handle service creation, database setup, and initial configuration. Within 10 minutes, you have a working PAM system.

Access Control​

You can create different permission levels:

  • Full admin access to all machines
  • Limited access for family members (maybe just the media server)
  • Temporary access for friends helping with projects

The permission system uses natural language patterns:

# Grant yourself admin access everywhere
orion-belt grant-permission --user admin --machine "*" --remote-user root

# Give your friend temporary access to the test server
orion-belt grant-permission --user friend --machine test-01 --remote-user deploy --expires 24h

Session Recording​

Every SSH session is recorded automatically. This is useful for:

  • Reviewing commands you ran during troubleshooting
  • Security audit if something goes wrong
  • Learning from others' sessions (great for homelab collaboration)

Sessions can be played back directly from the web interface or downloaded as text logs.

Resource Usage​

The gateway requires minimal resources (1 CPU, 1GB RAM, 10GB storage is plenty). Agents use about 5MB of memory and negligible CPU. For a typical homelab, the entire system runs comfortably on a $5/month VPS.

Next Steps​

The Homelab Setup Guide covers the complete installation process with specific examples for common homelab configurations.

entry.title: Orion-Belt is Now Open Source
entry.summary: Today marks an important milestone for Orion-Belt. After several months of private development and testing, the project is now publicly available on GitHub.
entry.content:
Today marks an important milestone for Orion-Belt. After several months of private development and testing, the project is now publicly available on GitHub.

From Private to Public​

Orion-Belt started as a personal project to solve a specific problem: managing secure SSH access across multiple machines without enterprise-level complexity or cost. The initial development happened in a private repository where I could experiment freely, make mistakes, and iterate on the architecture without worrying about maintaining a clean commit history for public consumption.

The system has been running in production environments since October, handling real workloads and proving its reliability. That production experience informed numerous design decisions and helped identify edge cases that wouldn't have been obvious from theoretical planning alone.

Preparing for Release​

Moving from private development to open source required more than just flipping a repository to public. The codebase needed preparation:

  • Cleaned up experimental code and dead-end implementations
  • Organized the commit history : mess to Initial commit ...
  • Created comprehensive documentation covering installation, configuration, and architecture
  • Wrote contribution guidelines and code of conduct
  • Set up issue templates and CI/CD workflows
  • Removed any hardcoded credentials or environment-specific configurations

The goal was to present a codebase that's production-ready and approachable for contributors. Someone cloning the repository should be able to understand the system architecture, run the tests, and deploy a working instance without needing to reverse-engineer undocumented decisions.

What's Available​

The public repository includes:

  • Complete source code for gateway server, agent, and client tools
  • Docker configurations and deployment scripts
  • Installation guides for major Linux distributions
  • OpenAPI specification and interactive documentation
  • Comprehensive test suite
  • Architecture diagrams and technical documentation

Looking for Contributors​

Open sourcing isn't just about making code available. It's about building a community around shared needs. I'm particularly interested in contributions from people who:

  • Run homelabs or self-hosted infrastructure
  • Manage SSH access for small to medium-sized deployments
  • Have experience with PAM systems and can provide architectural feedback
  • Want to add integrations with tools they already use
  • Can test on platforms and distributions I don't have access to

The project is stable and functional, but there's substantial room for improvement. The roadmap includes MFA support, certificate-based authentication, high availability features, and better observability tools. These are all areas where community input would be valuable.

Getting Involved​

The GitHub repository is the central hub for development. Start with the documentation to understand the system, try deploying it in your environment, and open issues for bugs or feature requests.

If you're interested in contributing code, check the issue tracker for tasks tagged as "good first issue" or "help wanted". The contribution guidelines explain the development workflow and testing requirements.

For questions or discussions that don't fit GitHub issues, there's a discussions board where you can ask about use cases, architecture decisions, or deployment strategies.

Next Steps​

The immediate focus is on improving documentation based on feedback from new users and fixing any issues that emerge as more people deploy the system in different environments.

Version 0.3.0 development has already started, focusing on MFA integration and SSH certificate authority support.

The project is now in your hands as much as mine. Looking forward to seeing where the community takes it.
